questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common anatomical position of the appendix?
questions.explanation:
Retrocaecal is the most common position of the appendix. Positions of appendix: • Retrocaecal: 74% • Pelvic: 21% • Sub-cecal: 1.5% • Pre-ileal: 1% • Post-ileal: 0.5% 548 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is not true regarding the various anatomical positions of the 
appendix?

options.a: Tenderness may be elicited on the immediate right of the umbilicus in post-ileal appendicitis
options.b: The most common location of the base of the appendix is retro-caecal
options.c: An inflamed pelvic appendix may cause an increase in frequency of micturition
options.d: Post-ileal appendicitis may have diarrhoea as a presenting complaint

questions.explanation:
The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum. Its 
position is constant. Conversely, the tip of the appendix can be found in many positions ( 
retrocaecal being the most common) The taeniae coli fuse to form the longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. During surgery, gentle 
traction at the taenia coli, leads the surgeon to the base of the appendix.

questions.question:
Question 3: During an appendectomy, the mesoappendix is divided and ligated. Which of the following is 
false about the major vessel ligated in this step?

options.b: It is a branch of upper division of the ileocolic artery
options.d: Thrombosis is most common at the tip

questions.explanation:
549 
Sold by @itachibot During appendectomy, the appendicular artery is the major vessel that is ligated when the 
mesoappendix is divided. It is a branch of the lower division of the ileocolic artery. The appendicular artery transverses behind the terminal ileum and enters the 
mesoappendix away from the base of the appendix. It lies along the free border of the 
mesoappendix. The terminal part or the tip of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may 
become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis. It supplies only the appendix and is an end-artery. An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam may be present. It anastomoses 
at the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.

questions.question:
Question 4: While assisting a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident use the Fold of Treves 
as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. Which of the following best 
describes the anatomical landmark? 539 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Mucous membrane projecting into the ileal lumen
options.b: The ilio-cecal fold of the peritoneum
options.c: The fold of the mucous membrane around appendiceal orifice
options.d: The fold of the peritoneum over ascending colon

questions.explanation:
550 
Sold by @itachibot Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum. A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions 
is the identification of the fold of Treves. It marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does 
not contain any vessel, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to 
determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to 
adjacent structures. Jackson Membrane: Adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending 
colon. Gerlach valves: A mucosal fold covering the appendiceal orifice.

questions.question:
Question 5: The CECT findings of a patient who presented with a positive McBurney's sign show a dilated 
appendix, appendicular wall thickening, and fat stranding. What is the initiating event that 
leads to his condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicitis. The initiating event in the development of 
appendicitis is luminal obstruction. Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute 
appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior 
iliac spine and umbilicus. It is where the appendix is commonly located. Due to the relatively small diameter of the appendicular lumen, it is easily obstructed. Usually, 
due to fecoliths. This leads to the buildup of mucus secretions and air due to bacteria. With 
progressive dilation, venous drainage may get hampered, leading to full-thickness ischemia and 
perforation. Obstructed lumen of appendix  Retained secretions with distension of lumen  Secretions get 
infected  Venous occlussion due to increased pressure  Bacterial translocation  Gangrene 
& perforation  Appendicular abscess 551 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: What is the earliest symptom in a patient with acute appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms of acute appendicitis begin as periumbilical pain followed by anorexia and nausea. Acute appendicitis begins with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain, first noticed in the 
periumbilical region. This is due to midgut visceral discomfort (T8 to T10 dermatomes) in 
response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction. Over the next 12-24 hours, it localises to the right lower quadrant due to local peritoneal 
inflammation.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient presents to the casualty with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On 
examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower 
quadrant. What is this sign is called?
questions.explanation:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea and right lower abdominal pain is 
Murphy's triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can 
cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called Rovsing’s sign. This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when 
the left lower abdomen is palpated.

questions.question:
Question 8: 540 
Sold by @itachibot You are examining a patient suspected to have appendicitis. During the given manoeuvre, you 
notice that the patient has sharp right-sided abdominal pain. Which of the following 
statements is false?

options.a: This sign elicited is known as Psoas Sign
options.b: It is commonly associated with pelvic appendicitis
options.c: Flexion of the hip against resistance may be done instead
options.d: Pain is due to contact of inflamed appendix with the psoas muscle

questions.explanation:
The manoeuvre in the given image shows hyperextension of the hip joint. It can induce abdominal 
pain when there is irritation of the psoas muscle by the inflamed appendix. This is known as the 
psoas sign and is commonly seen in retrocecal appendicitis. Flexion of the hip against resistance also elicits the psoas sign. Pain elicited on hip flexion and internal rotation is called the obturator sign. It is commonly seen 
in pelvic appendicitis. 552 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. On 
examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 104 beats/min. The CT scan image is 
shown below. Which of the following signs is not seen in this disease? 541 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The patient's history and radiological findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is 
not seen in acute appendicitis. Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include: • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter) • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement Ballance sign is seen due to a ruptured spleen. The ballance sign is positive if there is a fixed 
dullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. The 
fixed dullness is due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while the 
shifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity. Option A: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute 
appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior 
iliac spine and umbilicus. Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause 
pain in the right iliac fossa. Option C: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an in■amed appendix lies on the psoas 
muscle, and the patient will lie with the right hip ■exed, for pain relief.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for 
the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient is febrile. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac 
fossa is seen. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?

options.d: Erect X Ray of the abdomen

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of 
the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix. 
It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. 553 
Sold by @itachibot In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

questions.question:
Question 11: For which of the following criteria on the Alvarado system, will you assign 2 points to a 
patient with features of appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. In the 
Alvorado scoring system, leukocytosis  10 × 109 cells/L and tenderness right iliac fossa have two 
points.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following organisms is most commonly isolated in patients presenting with 
perforated appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
Bacteroides fragilis is the most common anaerobe and Escherichia coli is the most common 
aerobe isolated from perforated appendicitis. Type of bacteria 
Patients 
(%) Anaerobic Bacteria Bacteroides fragilis 
80 61 Bacteroides thetaiotaomicro 
n Bilophila wadsworthia 
55 Peptostreptococcusspp. 
46 Aerobic Bacteria E. coli 
77 Streptococcus viridians 
43 Group D streptococci 
27 Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
18

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain for the past week. On 
examination, tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa are present. An ill-defined 
abdominal mass is also palpated. CBC reveals leucocytosis. What is the next step in 
management?
questions.explanation:
In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical intervention 
may be difficult and dangerous. Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservative 
Ochsner–Sherren regimen is used.

questions.question:
Question 14: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy. 543 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the umbilicus, 
centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line 554 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It 
is also called McBurney incision. Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end 
over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the 
left side in the image for the sake of clarity) Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.question:
Question 15: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the 
incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut?
questions.explanation:
The structures cut when the initial incision gridiron incision (McBurney's incision) is converted to 
the Rutherford Morrison incision are the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse 
abdominis muscles. When the preoperative diagnosis is reasonably certain, the widely used incision for appendectomy 
is known as the gridiron incision. It is made perpendicular to a line connecting the anterior 
superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, with its center at McBurney's point. When better access is 
needed, the gridiron incision can be converted to a Rutherford Morison incision by extending the 
incision obliquely upwards and laterally. Rutherford Morison's incision is suitable for a para- or retrocecal appendix that is fixed. It is an 
oblique muscle-cutting incision starting from McBurney's point and extending upward and 
laterally as needed. All layers (skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, internal 
oblique, transversus abdominis, and the peritoneum) are divided along the incision line. In recent years, the transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has gained popularity due to improved 
exposure and ease of extension when necessary. This incision is placed approximately 2 cm below 
the umbilicus along the midclavicular-midinguinal line, with its length adjusted according to the 
patient's size and obesity. If required, the incision can be extended medially by retracting or 
dividing the rectus abdominis muscle (statement 4). 555 
Sold by @itachibot When there is uncertainty in the diagnosis, especially in the presence of intestinal obstruction, a 
lower midline abdominal incision is preferred over a right lower paramedian incision.

questions.question:
Question 16: As a surgical resident performing an appendectomy, what is the maximum stump size that 
you can leave behind in order to prevent stump appendicitis?
questions.explanation:
The residual appendiceal stump should be no longer than 5 mm, so as to minimize the possibility 
of stump appendicitis in the future. Stump appendicitis is a complication that occurs after an appendectomy. It is caused by the 
inflammation of the residual appendiceal tissue after the appendix is removed. The clinical 
presentation of stump appendicitis is similar to acute appendicitis. Factors predisposing for stump appendicitis: • Inadequate identification of the appendicular base due to severe local inflammation • Leaving a long stump due to fear of cecal injury or difficult dissection • Local ulcerations due to fecoliths.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 19-year-old boy is taken up for open appendicectomy. Which of the combinations of the 
following instruments is best suited for his procedure?
questions.explanation:
Babcock's forceps, 22 size blade, and Langenbeck retractor are used in open appendicectomy. The image below shows Babcock’s forceps, where: • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge 
out. • Tip is non traumatic with transverse serrations on it. • It has got a lock in proximal part. Uses: 556 
Sold by @itachibot • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc. The below image is that of a Langenbeck Retractor: • Useful for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. • Often used in pairs (one in each of the assistant’s hands). • The width of the lip of the retractors varies. 557 
Sold by @itachibot The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions 15-blade for minor surgical procedures. Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a 
cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. 558 
Sold by @itachibot Lane’s tissue holding forceps • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade • Apposing tooth in the tip • Lock in proximal part Uses: • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes. Tracheal dilator is used to keep tracheostomy open.

questions.question:
Question 18: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients who 
undergo an appendectomy ?
questions.explanation:
Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy. 559 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: What is the most common neoplasm of the appendix ? 545 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors. They account for approximately 66% of all tumors of the appendix. They are detected in 0.3 to 
0.9% of appendectomy specimens. Adenocarcinoma of the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. 
The adenocarcinoma malignancies are three subtypes: • Mucinous • Colonic type • Adenocarcinoid Mucinous is the most common subtype whereas Adenocarcinoid is the rarest.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is false about carcinoid tumours of appendix?

options.a: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behavior and metastatic potential
options.b: Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn
options.c: Most common location is the base of the appendix

questions.explanation:
The most common location of the carcinoid tumour of the appendix is the tip of the appendix i.e., 
the distal third of the appendix. A carcinoid tumour, also known as argentaffinoma, arises in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells of 
the crypts of Lieberkühn). It often presents with symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis. On gross examination, it is a moderately hard, yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and the 
peritoneum. Microscopically, tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle, 
and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B. Carcinoid tumours are the most common appendiceal tumours but they rarely metastasize. Treatment includes appendicectomy. Indications for right hemicolectomy along with 
appendectomy are : • Involvement of the cecal wall • Tumour is 2 cm or more in size • Lymph nodes are involved.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 35-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital for complaints of pain and tenderness 
in the right iliac fossa. She underwent an appendicectomy. A 2.5 cm tumor was encountered 
at the base of the appendix which was found to be carcinoid on histopathological 
examination. What is the next step in management?

options.b: Send the urine for 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid levels

questions.explanation:
The carcinoid tumors of the appendix which are more than 2 cm in size are treated with right 
hemicolectomy. Management of carcinoid tumors: • <1 cm – Appendicectomy 560 
Sold by @itachibot • 1-2 cms - Appendicectomy or right hemicolectomy depending on the individual tumor 
characteristics. • >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy Irrespective of size, it is recommended to perform a right hemicolectomy in: • Carcinoids at the appendiceal base (<2 cm from the base) • Lymphatic invasion or lymph node involvement • Spread to the mesoappendix • Tumor-positive resection margins • Cellular pleomorphism with a high mitotic index.

questions.question:
Question 22: Following an appendectomy, the specimen was sent for HPE. A well-circumscribed, yellowish 
tumor measuring 0.5 cm in diameter at the tip of the appendix was seen. The stained sections 
revealed a typical carcinoid tumor of the appendix. The specimen had a tumor-free margin on 
all sides. The base of the appendix, the mesoappendix, and nodes were not involved. What is 
the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
The size of the carcinoid tumour is 0.5 cm (<1 cm), the margins of the resected specimen are 
tumour free, and there is no involvement of appendix base, mesoappendix, or lymph nodes. The 
best management approach here is observation. Carcinoid tumour may be detected in ~0.5% of appendectomy specimens. Appendectomy is 
adequate in the treatment of cases with a diameter of <1 cm and in those with a diameter of 1-2 
cm without lymphovascular invasion. If a tumour is found after appendicectomy: • If it is an adenocarcinoma, perform right hemicolectomy. • If it is a carcinoid tumour, treatment differs according to the tumour size: • <1 cm – Observation • 1–2 cm – Right hemicolectomy if a lymphovascular invasion is seen • >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy Right hemicolectomy treatment is indicated even in tumours < 2 cm in case of: • Tumours localized at the base of the appendix • Invasion of lymphatic ducts, serosa and mesoappendix • Presence of regional lymph node metastasis • Positive surgical margins • Mucin production (mucinous carcinoid tumours) • High mitotic fast cellular pleomorphism

questions.question:
Question 23: A 6-year-old presented with right lower quadrant pain and fever for 1 day. An appendicitis 
was suspected and the patient was prepared for surgery. During the surgery, a normal 
appendix was found but mesenteric lymph nodes were enlarged. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammation of the terminal ileum, appendix, and cecum, 
alongwith mesenteric lymphadenopathy. It is the most common differential diagnosis of acute 561 
Sold by @itachibot appendicitis. Acute mesenteric lymphadenitis manifests as acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain 
associated with mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a normal appendix. Diagnosis is made 
after exploration of the abdomen of a patient suspected of having acute appendicitis, which 
reveals a normal appendix and enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes. It usually occurs in children 
and young adults.

questions.question:
Question 24: A postmenopausal lady diagnosed with mucinous cystadenoma appendix is unwilling for 
surgery. A few weeks later, she complains of vague abdominal pain and progressive 
abdominal distension. Ultrasound reveals the presence of ascites. CT reveals a thickened 
peritoneum, multiple loculated fluid collections, and scalloping of the liver and spleen 
margin. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

options.c: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
options.d: Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with mucinous cystadenoma appendix and imaging 
findings are suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei. Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a condition of mucinous ascites arising due to the rupture of a 
mucinous tumor of appendix or ovary. It most commonly occurs in patients between 40-50 years 
of age. They are often asymptomatic or present with non-specific complaints like abdominal pain 
and distension. Physical examination may reveal ascites with non shifting dullness and rarely, a palpable 
abdominal mass. CT scan may reveal accumulation of mucinous material and scalloped 
indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen. The peritoneal surfaces may be 
thickened due to the solid components of the tumor. The histology of the primary appendiceal 
tumor is an important predictor of survival. Management consists of extensive resection of the tumor (cytoreduction) and intraperitoneal 
heated chemotherapy (IPHC). Surgical management may include omentectomy, resection of the 
peritoneum and involved organs, appendectomy or a right hemicolectomy. 562 
Sold by @itachibot Polyps and Colorectal Carcinoma
